paragraph_text: The warranty claim process for customers:

Delta manufacture single stage hydraulic rod cylinders in a wide variety of lengths, piston diameter and stroke. Our products range in size from 38mm bore /150mm stroke to 500mm bore with a 9,000mm stroke.
Delta manufactures both single acting and double acting single stage rod cylinders.

Single-acting hydraulic cylinders have just one piston-head to which pressure is applied, meaning that its force is carried out in one direction and the return of the piston is either by its own weight, a load or an outside force.
Double acting rod cylinders are constructed with two opposed piston surfaces, meaning that they can work in two directions without reliance on an external force.

Our high quality single-stage rod cylinders are used in a wide variety of  OEM applications, such lift, steer, tilt and ejection bucket applications in mining and earth moving loaders and trucks, mast cylinders  for materials handling equipment and heave compensation cylinders for  ocean exploration drilling vessels.  Delta cylinders stand up to the rugged and corrosive environments of these applications.
We also provide cylinders for numerous industrial applications in the defence, energy, maritime and mining sectors.

For applications where the cylinder needs to operate in corrosive environments, Delta's cylinders can be chromed with Delta-C our proprietary corrosion resistant treatment  that extends the life of the cylinder ten fold.

Delta's competitive advantage in the global hydraulic market is its sophisticated in-house design, engineering and end-to-end manufacturing capability that enables the company to provide rapid and flexible design, engineering and manufacture and deliver precision quality product to our customers, that meets their requirements, whether it is a one-off project or high production volume OEM product.
Delta has 2D and 3D CAD designing and drafting with Finite Element Analysis (FEA) stress testing capability.

Our 8,300m2 manufacturing facility in Devonport and 9,000m2 facility in Thailand have extensive machining capabilities with an impressive range of CNC Lathes, CNC Turning Centres, CNC Machining Centres, Manual Lathes and Manual Mills. Our CNC Turning capacity utilises ten machines machining from 1000mm diameter x 3 metres down, with hollow spindle capacity to 520mm. Machine centres utilising six machines incorporating 4 axis horizontal, 4 axis vertical to 700 x 1200 x 600, and 3 axis vertical machines.

Our grinding capacity is second to none with centre grinding to 1000 diameter  x 7000 long, 3 centreless machines providing from 25-300 dia x 12000 long plus internal grinding to 500 ID x 400 long and surface grinding.
Internal cylinder surface finishing is achieved via a state of the art skiving-burnishing machines.
Delta has two friction welding machines, a 160 tonne machine, and a 650 tonne machine which is the largest friction welder in the southern hemisphere, as well as induction hardening machines.

Delta utilises the world's first horizontal reciprocating in-solution chrome plating machine which can chrome cylinders 12 metres in length and our vertical hard chrome facility is the largest in Australia. The 9 metre deep vertical tanks and solid state computer controlled rectifiers can handle work pieces up to 8.5 metres long and provide in process triplex plating.

Delta is ISO 9001:1994 certified and in 2015 will gain AS/NZS ISO 9001:2008 certification underpinned by a 6 Sigma operating system and utilising Caterpillar Production System (CPS) techniques.  Read more about

Delta has a Department of Defence certified 120 square metre clean room facility which is used for the production of manifolds and the  assembly of smaller cylinders for defence and medical applications.
It is also used as a hydraulic engineering training facility for college students.
Devonport is on the northern coast of Tasmania and sits in the centre of major sea and air freight infrastructure.
Delta Thailand is next to Caterpillar Underground Mining and opposite Caterpillar Tractor and Earthmoving in Rayong.
Delta has a 99% customer delivery KPI and absorbs additional freight costs to achieve ontime delivery if necessary.

Delta Hydraulics is an AS/NZS ISO 9001:2008 accredited manufacturer of hydraulic cylinders and related components and is an Australian Department of Defence Accredited Supplier.

Delta's Quality Management System (DQMS) is 6 Sigma based and encompasses all of the company's policies, procedures, work instructions and records in order to manage quality and facilitate continual improvement, so as to ensure the quality standards of Delta Hydraulics and its customers are met as well as customer requirements are met through customer focus.
Key operational elements of the Delta Quality Management System include:
Delta provides cylinder refurbishing and repairs for both telescopic and rod cylinders, for both small and large clients, including testing and quality inspections.

Where the cylinder is being used in quality controlled critical application such as defence or energy, then Delta's engineers and technicians can work to our customer's specific quality control requirement such as component specification and selection, refurbishment inspections and documentation.
If you have damaged or experienced a failure of a Delta Hydraulics product please complete the following online form and submit it.

The information will be reviewed by one of our quality control engineers and they will contact you for further information and then undertake an investigation into the causes of the failure and solutions.
Mandatory fields are marked with an *

Delta designs and manufactures annular ported double acting feed cylinders in both telescopic and rod designs. The types of cylinders incorporate ported inner cylinder walls, which enable the flow of hydraulic fluids that power the pistons to flow internally within the cylinder without the need for external hoses and tubing.

Annular ported cylinders are used in reliability critical applications where the operating environment could expose external hoses and tubes to physical damage, fire or chemical damage, or in applications where there is no space for external hoses and tubes.
Delta designs and manufactures both steel and aluminium hydraulic manifolds using cartridge valve inserts. We have a large range of tooling to suit all major suppliers of valve cartridges.

We have supplied manifold customers across a broad range of sectors including mining, and defence. Delta Hydraulics supplies manifolds to the Australian Submarine Corporation's Collins Class Submarines.
We also provide manifold testing, maintenance and refurbishing services.
Delhoist telescopic cylinders or hoists are the highest quality telescopic cylinders in the world offering unparalleled product life.
Delhoists are available as single-acting multi-stage hoists in a broad range of
. This type of cylinder applies hydraulic pressure in one direction only and the return of the telescopic stages is by load such as a truck-trailer.

Delhoist single-acting multi stage hoists are used widely throughout the transport sector, where they are used in tip trucks servicing agriculture, earthmoving, construction, food processing applications.
Delhoists are available as multi-acting multi-stage hoists in a broad range of

. This type of cylinder is constructed with porting to both the annular and full bore area so hydraulic pressure can be applied to both surfaces and the cylinder stages can move in multiple directions without the need of an outside force, such as gravity.

Delhoist double-acting multi-stage cylinders are used in a wide variety of applications across many industries where space restrictions prohibit the use of a rod cylinder and require a compact telescopic cylinder design.

Delhoists double-acting multi-stage cylinders are widely used in waste management sector in garbage and waste compactors, and in side-tippers  agricultural and food processing applications as well as ejector hoists in underground mining equipment.

Delta manufactures telescopic cylinders that deliver force with controlled constant velocity.  These cylinders are ideal for applications such as passenger lifts, or goods lifts, where there is a need to provide a smooth ride for comfort and safety control reasons.

Delta's sophisticated in-house design, engineering and end-to-end manufacturing capability enables us to develop customised single-acting or double-acting multi-stage telescopic hoists or cylinders for our customers.
We can build customised cylinders whether it is a one-off project or high production volume OEM product.
Delta Hydraulics manufactures a wide range of multi-stage telescopic cylinders and hoists as well as industrial single stage rod  hydraulic cylinders for OEM and industrial customers.

enables us to perform the full design, engineering and manufacturing cycle completely in-house.  This means that we can deliver both high volume products to our OEM clients as well as specialised cylinders for low-run or one-off projects.

Delta Hydraulics is a world leading manufacturer and innovator of multi-stage telescopic cylinders, industrial single rod hydraulic cylinders, constant velocity telescopic cylinders, long stroke mast cylinders, annular ported double acting telescopic feed cylinders and hydraulic manifolds.

Established in 1975 Delta has a long history of product and manufacturing innovation and has supplied hydraulic cylinders and related products to over 2,000 customers in more than 30 countries, across the industry segments of transport, waste management, mining, power generation, agriculture, aquaculture, defence, construction, earthmoving, energy, food and beverage processing, forestry, oil and gas exploration, materials-handling and ship-building.

Delta's sophisticated in-house design, engineering and end-to-end manufacturing capability enables us to provide rapid and flexible design, engineering and manufacture and deliver quality product to our customers whether it is a one-off project or high production volume OEM product.
Delta Hydraulics was established in 1975, by John White, who today remains the company's Managing Director and shareholder.

Delta is a world leading manufacturer and innovator of multi-stage telescopic cylinders and hoists, industrial single stage rod hydraulic cylinders, constant velocity telescoping cylinders, long stroke mast cylinders, annular ported double acting telescoping feed cylinders and manifolds.

Delta's wholly owned subsidiary, Delta Hydraulics Thailand Ltd, which was founded in 2013 and operates a 9,000 square metre manufacturing facility in Rayong, Thailand. This company manufactures hydraulic products for Caterpillar Inc.

Delta has a long history of product and manufacturing innovation and has supplied hydraulic cylinders and related products to over 2,000 customers in more than 30 countries, across the industry segments of agriculture, aquaculture, defence, construction, earthmoving, energy, food and beverage processing, forestry, oil and gas exploration, materials-handling, mining, power generation, ship-building, transport and waste management.

Delta's sophisticated in-house design, engineering and end-to-end manufacturing capability enables us to provide rapid and flexible design, engineering and manufacture and deliver quality product to our customers whether it is a one-off project or high production volume OEM product.

John founded Delta Hydraulics in 1975 and has led the company's innovation, engineering and sales since its inception and grown the company into an international operation with 17,000 m2 of advanced manufacturing plants on two continents with over 2,000 customers in 30 countries.

John, a self-taught engineer, is an innovator with numerous hydraulic innovation credits to his name including the development of unitary manufacture of telescopic stages as well as a range of engineered product  innovations in both telescopic and rod cylinders.  He applies his innovation and engineering precision to his other business interests and his hobby of high performance motorsport.

John is also the Managing Director of White Hot Industries, owner of White Sands Estate, Iron House Brewery, Iron House Distillery and IronHouse Vineyard on Tasmania's east coast and Managing Director of White Hot Motorsport and White Hot Marine.

Between 1985 and 2012 John served as a Director of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, including three years as President. Between 2011 and 2013 John was a Director of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Chairman of its Workplace Relations Committee.
John enjoys ocean fishing and motorsport and is a five-time winner of Targa Tasmania one of the world's most prestigious tarmac rallies.

Jason Bresnehan is Chief Operations Officer of the John White Group of Companies which incorporates Delta Hydraulics (Thailand) Ltd, Delta Hydraulics Australia Pty Ltd and business units in tourism, viticulture, brewing/distilling and property investment.
Jason commenced with Delta Hydraulics in 2015 and has been a key driver of the following achievements at Delta Hydraulics (Thailand) Ltd.
Jason holds a Bachelor of Business from the University of Tasmania and commenced his career as an accountant, working for six years in chartered accountancy firms including four years with KPMG.

Post KPMG Jason was a partner in a boutique investment banking firm Noble House Investment Banking and between 1998 and 2004 Jason was a venture capitalist with Momentum Ventures, a $30m early stage technology fund which invested in drug, medical, point of use, enterprise software and oil & gas exploration technologies.

Jason has led three companies; Imagination Software - a developer of browser based web applications, Funnelback - a provider of a cloud based enterprise search application and Biovend - a developer of point of use vending freezers for the global life sciences and medical research sectors.
Before joining Delta Jason was COO/CFO of the Pescott Group, a $120 million group of businesses in the forestry, farming, recycling and rubber products manufacturing sectors.
Jason enjoys competing in tarmac rallies and circuit racing.

Robert commenced with Delta Hydraulics in December 1992 and for 26 years was Delta's Chief Design and Drafting Engineer.  In 2019 Robert was appointed Chief Production Officer and is responsible for Delta's 100 production employees and the quality and timely production of Delta's range of OEM hydraulic cylinders, customised hydraulic cylinders and related parts.
Robert also provides redundancy in the Sales/Quoting area and manages Delta's information technology infrastructure. Robert is also responsible for Human Resources Management for Delta.

Robert began his career with the Australian Department of Defence and was involved in the design of tooling, jigs, fixtures, gauging and machine design associated with the production of small firearms. He then joined the Royal Australian Airforce and managed the drawing office of the Publications division.
Robert is a qualified Fitter & Turner and holds an Associate Diploma in Mechanical Engineering and a Diploma in Competitive Systems and Practices (Lean Manufacturing).
Simon was appointed Chef Design and Drafting Engineer in February 2019.

Simon joined Delta in 2003 leaving in 2009 to take a drafting position at RGE, specialists in the manufacture and installation of fibreglass reinforced plastic products. Between 2012 and 2014 Simon undertook contracting drafting for the food processing sector in North West Tasmania including global companies such as Simplot.

Rejoining Delta in 2014 Simon is an experienced design and drafting engineer for hydraulic single rod cylinders as well as telescopic cylinders.  Simon has completed hundreds of hydraulic cylinder designs which have been manufactured and deployed in over 30 countries in a diverse range of applications such as mining, transport, materials handling, agriculture, forestry, shipbuilding, food processing as well as oil and gas exploration.
Simon holds a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering, an Advanced Diploma in Mechanical Engineering and a Diploma in Civil Engineering.

Delta Hydraulics was established in 1975 and in 2013 it launched its first international subsidiary Delta Hydraulics (Thailand) Ltd.  The group employs 115 people and is headquartered in Devonport, Australia, a northern coastal city on the island state of Tasmania.

Delta Hydraulics is a world leading manufacturer and innovator of double-acting and single-acting multi-stage telescopic cylinders and hoists, industrial single stage rod hydraulic cylinders in both single-acting and double-acting designs, constant velocity telescoping cylinders, annular ported double acting telescoping feed cylinders and manifolds.

Delta has supplied hydraulic cylinders and related products to over 2,000 customers in more than 30 countries, across the industry segments of transport, waste management, mining, power generation, agriculture, aquaculture, defence, construction, earthmoving, energy, food and beverage processing, forestry, oil and gas exploration, materials-handling and ship-building.

Delta-C  is Delta Hydraulics' world leading proprietary ceramic densifying  chrome hardening treatment,  that provides hard chrome corrosion protection that is more than 100 times the standard set by leading OEMs.

Hard chrome is commonly used in hydraulic piston rods to provide corrosion and wear resistance but due to its porosity corrosive fluids and contaminants can penetrate the chrome and cause it to debond from the substrate.

Delta-C treatment eliminates this porosity and micro-cracking by sealing the pores and fissures in the chrome and bonding with it to provide an extremely hard smooth surface. Corrosives and contaminants can no longer penetrate the chrome to cause damage.
Hydraulic cylinders incorporating Delta-C treatment components have applications where the hydraulic cylinders need to operate in harsh environments such as:
Delta-C treated hydraulic rods have been subjected to 10,000 hours of salt spray testing with no visible corrosion recorded.
Delta-C application is carried out in our Australian manufacturing facility by highly skilled professional personnel specifically trained in the proprietary procedure.

DEVONPORT, TASMANIA - The principles of hydraulic systems are an integral part of the transport and earthmoving industries, and yet they remain a very specialised area of expertise. In simplistic terms, the principles of hydraulics are defined as relating to a liquid moving in a confined space under pressure.

Unlike a mechanical breakdown, which in the most part simply means the vehicle in question will stop somewhere, a hydraulic failure usually has the potential to become messy as the fluid under pressure escapes, plus it has the potential to itself create injury amongst those working in close proximity.

Delta Hydraulics was established in Tasmania by John White and two other business partners in 1975, when each partner contributed up to $1000 to get the company up and running. With the business growing rapidly, John subsequently bought out the shares of the other two business partners and to this day John White remains the sole owner, with the company headquarters based in Devonport, Tasmania.

Prior to his involvement in Delta Hydraulics, John’s background was that of a dairy farmer, who was then conscripted to service in the Vietnam War. While John was never sent to Vietnam, he was involved in multiple roles with the Australian Army. These included managing a number of workshops for the army’s varied range of trucks, earthmoving equipment and other plant from the Puckapunyal base in central Victoria.

It was during this tenure with the defence forces that John learnt about hydraulics and what they could achieve, and, as a qualified fitter and turner, hydraulics was of particular interest. It was a very different industry then from today, with the late 1960s featuring front-end loaders being produced and operated using pulleys and cables, rather than full hydraulic power.

Delta is a business that specialises in the manufacture and repair of hydraulic cylinders, with the core products produced by the business including single and doubleacting multi-stage telescopic cylinders, single and double-acting single-stage rod cylinders, annular ported telescopic feed cylinders, hydraulic power packs, manifolds, directional valves, cylinder refurbishing and repairs.

The company’s headquarters in Devonport, Tasmania, also house the production facilities on-site for manufacturing and repairs to hydraulic cylinders. It’s here that Delta employs over 100 people, to cover the requirements of administration, engineering, purchasing and stores, spare parts and manufacturing. As a small town of just over 30,000 people, Delta is most important to the regional economy of Devonport, both through its direct employment and flow-on effects to the community via the related service industries that work with Delta.

In addition to the Tasmanian operations, Delta operates a facility in Thailand of 9000 square metres to provide additional manufacturing capacity and superior service to the Asian region for hydraulic cylinders and related products.

Delta exists as both a supplier and manufacturer of OEM parts to multinational earthmoving equipment including Caterpillar. The company also produces specially designed hydraulic cylinders for the underground mining industry.

With regards to road transport, Delta supplies hydraulic systems to a range of bodybuilders that supply specific vocations in the industry. For example, Delta is a major supplier to Superior Pak, the manufacturer of waste bodies and compactors. Delta also supplies hydraulic systems and equipment to rigid tipper bodybuilders and trailer manufacturers, including Hercules and Tefco.
Delta’s multistage tipping cylinders sold under the Delhoist brand are known for their extended service life, with a strong reputation that can be attributed to a number of unique design factors.

The company was the first to chrome plate multistage cylinders, which extends the service life of the cylinder as it prevents corrosion of the stages and also extends the seal life. The twin-lip seal and also the flapped wiper used by Delta reduce contamination such as dust and moisture entering the cylinder. John White’s unique design eliminates the need for gland nuts or base plugs in Delhoist’s cylinders, which further extends the service lifeof the cylinder.

When mounted on tip trucks only a single acting hoist is required as hydraulic pressure is only required to raise the body, and gravity acts to lower the body once the tipping has occurred. For applications such as found in the waste compactor market, the requirement is for double acting cylinders as hydraulic power is required to both open and close the ram when undertaking operations.

Another aspect of Delta’s business is with the ongoing maintenance and supply of hydraulic componentry to the Australian Navy for its Collins Class submarines. As these submarines are on strict maintenance schedules,

Delta is relied upon for providing hydraulic components both of high quality and on demand to minimise time the submarines are out of service for repairs and maintenance. An onsite clean room is used for the manufacture of navy components as well as additional capacity for medical applications.

One of the particularly impressive features at Delta’s Devonport factory is its friction welder, which is the largest in the southern hemisphere. John explains the friction welder allows for much quicker, and ultimately cheaper production costs compared with using a forge.

Friction welding (FRW) is a solid-state welding process that generates heat through mechanical friction between work pieces in relative motion to one another, with the addition of a lateral force called “upset” to plastically displace and fuse the materials. Because no melting occurs, friction welding is not a fusion welding process in the traditional sense, but more of a forge welding technique. Friction welding is used with metals and thermoplastics in a wide variety of aviation and automotive applications.

“Delta’s sophisticated in-house design, engineering and end-to-end manufacturing capability enable us to provide rapid and flexible design, engineering and manufacture, and deliver quality product to our customers whether it is a one-off project or high production volume OEM product,” said John.

“Sophisticated capability enables us to perform the full design, engineering and manufacturing cycle completely in-house. This means that we can deliver both high volume products to our OEM clients as well as specialised cylinders for low-run or one-off projects” he added.

The paint shop at Delta’s Devonport operation can supply all cylinders in the specific colours of the customer’s requirements, such as in genuine Caterpillar yellow or customer preferences for individual pieces of equipment.
Delta also has onsite chroming facilities to chrome plate the hydraulic cylinder rods.

The system used by Delta provides chrome-plating protection 100 times greater than those demanded by many OEMs. The main role of chrome plating is to prevent corrosion, which would ultimately damage the seal and subsequently cause hydraulic fluid leakages around the cylinder. The chrome plating at Delta is particularly advantageous in operations where there is high exposure to corrosive environments such as mining or marine applications.

As testimony to the product quality produced by Delta, the company is ISO 9001 certified with AS/NZS ISO 9001:2008 certification. This is further underpinned by a 6 Sigma operating system utilising Caterpillar Production System (CPS) techniques.

The future for Delta on a global basis looks set to grow steadily in response to the increasing applications and usage of hydraulics in a diverse range of industries. The growing emphasis on the use of robotics in manufacturing plants will also play a part in the expansion of the hydraulics industry as well as in agriculture where advanced machinery is used to both sow and pick vegetable and fruit crops.

HOBART, TASMANIA - The Delta Hydraulic's Dodge Viper duo of John and Jason White secured their 7th Targa Tasmania win.
The Delta Hydraulics prepared Viper withstood ailing tyres to produce a stunning victory in one of the world's showpiece tarmac rally, Targa Tasmania.
After just under 500km of competitive distance across 33 special stages, the Whites set the pace at the front all week.

Leading from the outset, the Dodge Viper duo have now moved to within one win of the all-time event winning record set by the highly decorated former touring car champion Jim Richards and former long-time commentator Barry Oliver.
John White said "the win is a testament to Jason's outstanding driving ability and the engineering excellence of Delta Hydraulics engineers who prepared the race car".
Tasmania has made significant improvements in the Defence Force industry says Defence Industry Minister Christopher Pyne.
Mr Pyne toured Devonport’s Delta Hydraulics, who recently signed a 40-year contract to be part of the sustainment and maintenance of the Collins class sonar upgrade.
Production administrator Viv Woodward said this would be the company’s second biggest customer.
“It gives Delta Hydraulics a good look into the future,” Mr Woodward said.
“A 40-year contract is a large time. Most of the people working here right now probably won’t be here in 40 years.
“Every year we put on apprentices to make sure there is a constant flow of tradesmen coming through the place and while we do that I think the future looks really bright.”
Mr Pyne said Tasmania was doing a fair share of work for the Defence Force.

“A year ago … I was talking about how one of the things about Tasmania was that you have a very large, small and medium enterprise-based economy that’s diffused, but the defence industry wasn’t pulled together in a way that it could be and since then the state government and the Australian Industry Defence Network here in Tasmania have pulled that group of people together.”
A 40-year contract is a large time. Most of the people working here right now probably won’t be here in 40 years.
Labor senator Anne Urquhart said she felt Mr Payne’s visit to Devonport raised more questions than answers.
“Will this actually create any new jobs on the North-West Coast. Was this just a publicity stunt?” she said.

Mr Pyne was also in Tasmania to witness Thales Australia, the University of Tasmania, Australian Maritime College and AMOG Consulting sign a memorandum of understanding to investigate the establishment of a test facility for submarine and surface ship sonar systems.
The potential locations being investigated for the facility were located in Braddon and would create jobs and develop world-leading expertise for the region.
My Pyne said the contracts were for two reasons.

“Firstly investing that amount of money into our Defence Force industry and our defence capability. Secondly insisting that we do as much of it as possible here in Australia. This is a national enterprise and Tasmania is a big part of that.”
DEVONPORT,TASMANIA - Tasmania has made significant improvements in the defence force industry says Minister for Defence Industry Christopher Pyne.
Mr Pyne toured Devonport's Delta Hydraulics, who recently signed a 40-year contract to be part of the sustainment and maintenance of the Collins class sonar upgrade.
Production administrator Viv Woodward said this would be their second biggest customer.
"It gives Delta Hydraulics a good look into the future. A 40-year contract is a large time. Most of the people working here right now probably won't be here in 40 years." Mr Woodward said.
"Every year we put on apprentices to make sure there is a constant flow of tradesmen coming through the place and while we do that I think the future looks really bright."
Mr Pyne said Tasmania was doing a fair share of work for the defence force.

"A year ago ... (I) was talking about how one of the things about Tasmania was that you have a very large, small and medium enterprise based economy that's defuse, but the defence industry wasn't pulled together in a way that it could be and since then the state government and the Australian Industry Defence Network here in Tasmania have pulled that group of people together."
Labor Senator Anne Urquhart said she felt Mr Payne's visit to Devonport raised more questions than answers.
"Will this actually create any new jobs on the North-West Coast. Was this just a publicity stunt," she said.
"Like everything with this Turnbull Government, the devil is in the detail."

Mr Pyne was also in Tasmania to witness Thales Australia, the University of Tasmania, Australian Maritime College and AMOG Consulting sign a memorandum of understanding to investigate the establishment of state-of-the-art trials and test facility for submarine and surface ship sonar systems.
The potential locations being investigated for the facility are located in Braddon and will create jobs and develop world-leading expertise for the region.
"All of these contracts these big injections of the economy into Tasmania would not be happening if the Turnbull government weren't doing two things," Mr Pyne said.
"Firstly investing that amount of money into our defence force industry and our defence capability."
"Secondly insisting that we do as much of it as possible here in Australia. This is a national enterprise and Tasmania is a big part of that."
Thales Australia advises the use of Tasmania's deep, cold and acoustically quiet lakes for the proposed acoustic testing capability could enable sonar systems.
Delta Hydraulics is pleased to announce the appointment of Simon Morris as Chief Design and Drafting Engineer.

Simon joined Delta in 2003 leaving in 2009 to take a drafting position at RGE, specialists in the manufacture and installation of fibreglass reinforced plastic products . Between 2012 and 2014 Simon undertook contracting drafting for the food processing sector in North West Tasmania including global companies such as Simplot.

Rejoining Delta in 2014 Simon is an experienced design and drafting engineer for hydraulic single rod cylinders as well as telescopic cylinders.  Simon has completed hundreds of hydraulic cylinder designs which have been manufactured and deployed in over 30 countries in a diverse range of applications such as mining, transport, materials handling, agriculture, forestry, shipbuilding, food processing as well as oil and gas exploration.
Simon holds a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering, an Advanced Diploma in Mechanical Engineering and a Diploma in Civil Engineering.

Robert commenced with Delta Hydraulics in December 1992 and for 26 years was Delta’s Chief Design and Drafting Engineer.  In 2019 Robert was appointed Chief Production Officer and is responsible for Delta’s 100 production employees and the quality and timely production of Delta’s range of OEM hydraulic cylinders, customised hydraulic cylinders and related parts.
Robert also provides redundancy in the Sales/Quoting area and manages Delta’s information technology infrastructure. Robert is also responsible for Human Resources Management for Delta.

Robert began his career with the Australian Department of Defence and was involved in the design of tooling, jigs, fixtures, gauging and machine design associated with the production of small firearms. He then joined the Royal Australian Airforce and managed the drawing office of the Publications division.
Robert is a qualified Fitter & Turner and holds an Associate Diploma in Mechanical Engineering and a Diploma in Competitive Systems and Practices (Lean Manufacturing).

Devonport is becoming a magnet for a new breed of ambitious young people who are setting up businesses locally and having a crack.
We have become one of the best places in Tasmania to start a family, start a life and grow a business.
We all know that Tasmania is one of the best places in the world, and 'Heavenport' has the best of what Tassie has to offer.
This is when young people in major cities are starting to sit up and take notice of the opportunities in regional Australia.
Positive: Devonport Chamber of Commerce and Industry president Dane Layton says the city is well on the up.
Positive: Devonport Chamber of Commerce and Industry president Dane Layton says the city is well on the up.
There is a ready market of ambitious "house price refugees" living in Sydney and Melbourne who have been yearning to quit the rat-race (and the traffic) and move to greener pastures.
Somewhere they can buy a house.
Somewhere they can set down roots.
Somewhere they can afford to follow their big dreams.
Devonport is becoming a national hot spot for these go-getters.
Some of them are locals who moved away and have come back with new skills, new partners and new ambitions and a family to raise in the best place to do so.
Some are coming to live here for the first time. In the last 12 months, 250 new businesses have registered in Devonport.
We've got the next generation of winners setting up all over town.

Justin Arnold and Alicia Peardon from Ghost Rock have come home to take over the family business and have been filling their trophy cabinet with accolades since their return. Their wines are now being sold all over the world, showing off what our region can do.

Tom Sullivan from Fundamental Espresso has brought back mainland espresso culture and has been energising the Devonport with his top class coffee since the new multi-storey carpark was a hole in the ground. He has cited an increase in confidence and activity in Devonport as his reason for taking the leap and starting his own business.
Paul Fielding from Bistro Camille, Pear Oyster Bar + Café and the newly opened Lulu Café is positioning himself as a provider of fine food for the Devonport tourist market.

And Luke from Beardwood Constructions has seen 900% revenue growth since 2016-17 and won the prestigious DCCI 2019 Business of the Year Award. Beardwood has large and small projects statewide with crews all over Tasmania and have chosen to keep their base operations in Devonport.
As a business ecosystem we're big enough to sustain growth but small enough that we don't crowd out the green shoots.
Our population is also growing, and Devonport is the business hub for Latrobe and Port Sorell, one of the fastest growing local government areas in Tasmania.
Three of Australia's top 500 biggest private companies have strong links to our city - Vos Construction, SeaRoad and Petuna.
Nearby we also have international exporters like Premium Fresh, Harvest Moon, and Delta Hydraulics outcompeting producers and manufacturers all over the world.
But we have not always been able to successfully attract the new breed.
A decade ago Devonport was tired and lethargic. Now that couldn't be further from truth.
A decade ago Devonport was tired and lethargic. Now that couldn't be further from truth.
It is no coincidence that Tasmania's largest ever regional urban renewal project is acting like a magnet for new businesses, new jobs and new families.
And we're not even half way through yet.
Our region has always had a great story.

We live in a stunning coastal city with a working port in Australia's most beautiful state (that the rest of the country is starting to sit up and take notice of). We have a temperate climate, affordable housing, the best soils and top quality infrastructure, where kids can grow up safe, people are friendly and we don't take ourselves too seriously.

But what's new, and attracting the new breed, is an unprecedented investment in the economic future of this place. Federal, state and local government have all been investing strongly in the future of Devonport and the ambitious new breed are seeing the signs of what is to come.
We are on the cusp of some big changes here in Devonport and it is incredibly exciting.
Devonport now has a vision for its future and we're getting on with making it a reality.
That is acting like a magnet for small businesses and young families to set up shop and have a crack.
Put simply, the new breed love us for what we are and are excited about where we're going.

Dane Layton is president of the Devonport Chamber of Commerce and Industry. In 2015, after working for nine years in architecture in Launceston, he moved back home to Devonport to run Drift café/restaurant and continues to work in architecture in the region, which is showing solid signs of growth.

Delhoist single-acting and Delhoist double-acting telescopic cylinders are used for hydraulic applications such as truck-trailer tipping, hoisting, side tipping and waste compactors.
They are available in top trunnion mounted (TT Series) or bottom trunnion mounted (BT Series) configurations and provide tipping or hoisting capacities ranging from 7.3 tonne to 60 tonne.
Outer barrel dimensions of the TT and BT Series hoists range from 3.5" (8.89cm) to 9.7" (24.6cm).
We also manufacture single stage and double acting telescopic cylinders for custom and OEM applications. For example we manufacture telescopic cylinders for waste management compactors.

ADELAIDE, SOUTH AUSTRALIA - After 4 days in sometimes trying conditions the Delta Hydraulics and Whitehot Motorsport crew of John and Jason White have taken out Targa Adelaide in their first attempt.
The Delta Hydraulics team leverage their precision engineering skills to build the best tarmac rally car in the world.
At their first attempt John and Jason have conquered Targa Adelaide 2012. In often trying conditions they led from the front from day 1 and were never headed.

An inspired choice of soft tyres proved decisive on the first 3 days as conditions more often than not quite wet , cold and slippery. Day 1 claimed a couple of big scalps, Event sponsor Kevin Weeks crashed on SS7 Castanbul and the next stage saw the demise of local hope Sims and Sims in their Nissan GTR.
The next couple of days saw the Whites lead ease out to 44 seconds from Tony Quinn in his GTR.
Day four was fine and the soft tyre choice almost bought the team undone , but the had enough time in hand to hang on from a fast finishing Quinn followed by the Rullo GTR in Third.
The boys also battled a few issues along the way from broken Driveshafts , worn out clutches and an intermittent 'miss' but came out in front at the end.

DEVONPORT, TASMANIA - The head of a north-west Tasmanian manufacturing plant says the Federal Government's economic stimulus package will do nothing to save jobs at his business.
Delta Hydraulics in Devonport makes cylinders for the power generation, transport and mining and defence industries.
Managing Director John White says he has recently cut 23 jobs from his work force of 122, due to a reduction in international orders.
He says the Government's package is offering help to buy new equipment but that is of no use to him as he is not fully using his current equipment.
"Our local economy relies on people like ourselves to employ people and keep the whole thing turning, but I'm afraid that the stimulus package will have a very, very small effect on us," he said.
